Diet & Body Re-composition

Initial Body Fat and Body Composition Changes

General Philosophies of Muscle Mass Gain

Sample Diets
Read the above articles, and decide whether you need to bulk (add muscle), cut (lose fat), or maintain.

Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) in calories

Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories
Protein: 1+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories
Protein: 1.5+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

posts.com:
Hey /fit/,

It's been 6 long years since lurking here, but I thought I'd pop in to wish you all well in your training goals. Hope you've been well.

Just a reminder that consistency and patience is what gets you long term results.

I've been training for 11 years mix of bodybuilding, powerlifting, weightlifting, athletics and calisthenics and natty as well.

Never competed and don't really want to, just have been training for mental well-being more than anything.

>Left is back in 2011 at 16 years old @52kg
>Right is this week, 27 years old @92kg

As someone who has seen way too many kids wanting results quick, you just have to wait it out. Rome wasn't built in a day and neither will you.

If you have any questions I'll be on for a short while before getting back to business.

>we're all gonna make it
As long as we keep going forward.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Christmas edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For lard lads who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Previous Thread >>69330755

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69348883
Wow, nice going anon. What has your diet/exercise regime been?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69348973

OMAD the first few months. Meals consisted of scrambled eggs (add whatever you want, I used ham, cheese, onions and tomatoes) or sandwiches, or some combination of the two, and then a bunch of vegetables on the side: spinach, carrots, sugar snap or snow peas, tomatoes.

But that wasn't enough protein, so now I cook a bunch of chicken every weekend. Meals are chicken, hard-boiled eggs, cottage cheese, and all the same vegetables as before.

Also started having a snack or two around midday, so not strictly OMAD before. Usually just plain greek yogurt with 5g of honey.

For exercise, I didn't do anything to start, other than walking dogs 30-60 minutes every day, which I have always done. Its better if you do exercise/lift, but its not strictly necessary to lose weight/fat. To me its easier to change one shit habit at a time than multiple, and I didn't mind losing muscle mass, I just wanted to get unfat first. I know how to put lean mass back on, so not really worried about it. Last couple of months I started doing pullups and hanging leg raises every day, plus adding in one of pushups, OHP+ lateral raise with kettlebells, or goblet squats. Thats mostly to ease my body into working out again before I start lifting more seriously, since I hadn't done shit for seven years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69349476

bioelectric impedance, which is what those scales use to measure body fat, isn't super accurate. So I wouldn't necessarily trust -0.2%, at least in a vacuum. If you are taking other measurements and that matches up then sure.

Like I measure body fat with scale and also circumference method (how we measured it in military...waist circ-neck circ = value you look up on table based on height). That's not accurate either, but it and the scale measurements are typically within 1% of each other. And I also keep track of the circumference measurements themselves, so I can see my waist getting smaller over time through that, even if I can't tell in the mirror week to week.

Depends where your at, and there's no way for me to know that. You want to build muscle to burn fat, and to do that you want to reach muscle failure as efficiently as possible.

This also depends a lot in your situation. Program compliance is a thing, so if I were to tell you the perfect foods it means nothing if you won't exclusively eat it, or if it's not available. Beef is great if you can afford it. Limiting carbs is generally good, but not required, total calories is more significant. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69353364
>Stationary bike
That can fuck up your pudendal nerve and ruin your dick. Sell it or get the wide seat.
>Food
I used to eat tuna with mustard (not mayo) with spinach and onion wrapped in whole wheat tortillas. That was in my thirties. It helped I worked in Mexican Town and had access to fresh tortillas with minimal additives.
If you got to do lunch meat, roast beef is best. Minimal calories, maximum protein. In fact it's hard to go wrong with beef. If you aren't lactose intolerant, skim milk is very underrated. It's 50/50 lactose(carb)/protein.
For satiety, baked/boiled potato is undisputed king. In my twenties I lost weight eating Wendy's baked potato with chili, but their chili sucks now, make your own. They put high fructose corn syrup in it.
Water or green tea is the best thing to drink, but in my opinion the least offensive artificial sweetener is sucralose.
Don't worry about dietary fat beyond it's calorie value, just worry about the quality of said fats.
>Exercise
Constancy and good form is more important than the perfect routine. Recovery is very important as well. Sleep is a must.
Also, watch out for the fact that burning fat makes you tired and depressed. Don't trust your emotional state. Trust your scale and tape measure. Even then, don't be discouraged by the appearance of back sliding. Your weight might go up or your waist might get bigger at first. Give it two weeks.
If you are at reduced calorie count expect the cravings and disorientation to last three weeks or even a month.
Just stick to your basics and keep your mind distracted.
Good luck!

Plus, abdominal obesity is usually worse than regular obesity unless you’re really morbidly obese. You’re still at a dangerously high body fat percentage but you’ve got a lower ratio of lean mass than before. So it’s not only gross looking but still very unhealthy. When I started losing weight I was at about 45~50% body fat, and I wanted to lose 30kg. After losing 20kg, I was still at 30% body fat, so I recognised that I had a problem. I lost another 10kg but built up enough muscle mass that I ended up at 14% body fat after only 3 more months of effort. It’s not super difficult to escape being skinnyfat, so to any skinnyfat anons reading this rn, please start doing something about it today. You’ll thank yourself later.

previous: >>69316371

>Advice for new runners
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 mi. (10km), start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training routine for that race

I used to live close enough to work that I could just run home every other day, but I've moved further away it's become quite complicated.
The simplest way for me to maintain a regular running schedule would be to integrate it into the first half of my evening commute, but that'd mean I'd be hot and sweaty for a good hour before being able to shower. Has anyone dealt with something like this before? Lingering sweat tends to break out my skin, and I'm not sure what I'd be in for with roon-tier sweat.
I was thinking of keeping a wet rag in a bag with me to wipe down my face at least upon finishing, maybe that'd at least take the edge off, but that might not be enough.

Also, I perform much better in the evening rather than the morning, but morning runs would sidestep the above issue. If I were to almost exclusively run in the morning, would that bottleneck my progress? Or is it all relative and exertion is exertion, whether it's an 8/10 effort with a bad pace due to bad conditions or an 8/10 effort with a good pace due to good conditions?

>Most fats that are liquid at room temperature are healthy, though many cooking oils, including seed oils, contain another kind of fat that is far worse than saturated fats (solid at room temperature). using steroids is bad for you. if your goal is achievable without using steroids then don't use them. if your goal is not achievable without using steroids then you've already acquired brainworms no matter how far into self-denial you are and you will proceed down the road towards one of three destinations:

these are the three ways your story can end. but there is no point where someone who uses roids gets to a point and thinks "hmm y'know i'm big enough now :)" and spends the rest of their life cruising. some people feel the dysmorphia less intensely and so pursue more reasonable and less frequent blasts, others are constrained by time or money, but nobody's taking steroids because they DON'T want to be big and get bigger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69349010
Not 30+ yet (just about to turn 30), but I've had to adjust many times while traveling for work. Generally, I'll have a plan for which lifts I want to do, and then I'll switch stuff up if I need to. Some days, my hips and back are tight from driving and flying, so I'll swap out a lift that doesn't feel great that day. Some days, I have a little wear and tear from work or other activities, and I'll have to be aware of it and work around it. For example, if I've been doing a lot of overhead screwdriver work, it helps to use dumbbell presses instead of barbell to pay extra attention to a cranky shoulder and not accidentally force it with the happy one.
If I'm coming in just tired for whatever reason, I'll normally feel it in the warmups and just take a lighter weight for high reps.
There are even some days when I'm dropping in at a random gym in bumfuck nowhere, and I just don't have the equipment to do certain things. Sometimes you have to get creative, or just accept that it's better to try the next day when you have better access or feel better. More rest is better than forcing it, especially if your recovery is compromised for some reason.
The thing that matters is getting the stimulus in for the muscle group you're targeting. Different exercises, rep schemes, etc are just different tools to accomplish that.

>>69346014
I am 31.
I powerbloated when I was 17-20, then pretty much quit lifting. Reached a BW of 200lbs+, 5'10" height.
Sort of randomly lost most of the blubber over the last decade, I am now 170lbs with abs but not really lean. The lifting during my teens seem to have permanently changed my morphological "defaults" and I held on to a decent amount of lean mass and strength despite being nearly inactive for a decade.

Started lifting again about 3 months ago, bulked up from 163lbs. Prior to that I did some casual calisthenics and running.
General health and athleticism is higher than during my powerbloatlifter days for sure.
Slowly recouping strength gains, doing it smart and controlled for squats and deadlifts to avoid any injuries. Planning on bulking up to 180-190lbs during the next year while recouping and surpassing previous lifts.
I believe late 20's/early 30's is the cut-off point for where you need to take your health serious if you want to age well.
As for difference in lifting, not much. Except that joints and ligaments/tendons don't recover as fast, you need to watch the volume/frequency on big lifts more carefully. I never purposefully deloaded as a teenager despite going full retard yolo lifting every single session, now it seems around 5-6 weeks with my current schedule (upper/lower 4-5 times a week) is required.

>>69349010
35 anon here. I've condensed by weight lifting into what I know works for me. I achieved my lifting goals back in my twenties, so I'm not into going heavy and hard each session, or ego-lifting, or breaking any big PRs. I only care about what keeps me strong, keeps me functional, and keeps me adaptable.

With that being said, I knock out my weights on Saturdays and Sundays and hit everything on those two days. Then I spend M-F doing running, swimming, stretches, and foam rolling to keep my heart healthy (family history of heart disease) and stay flexible. Following this method, I could literally run laps around my younger self and lift more than he ever could. It's not a joke how much a strong, healthy heart can completely change things if you've got good lifting base to work from.

>>69346014
36 here

Overall performance (max lifts, cardio, etc) is better than it’s ever been. I feel fucking great. Part of that is I’ve learned a lot about diet, exercise, recovery, etc and take better care of myself. Much of this was done through trial and error and learning the hard way. I wish I could reboot at 16 with my current knowledge, but I guess every old guy kinda wants that.

Durability is becoming a concern. Injuries are a little easier to come by compared to my 20s and tend to linger. Nothing dramatic, but little aches and pains can pop up and stay a while even without any obvious initial injury prompting it.

Your 30s are going to be a product of decisions you made and work you put in during your teens and 20s. Health wise, career wise, etc. I think it’s one of the best times in life if you’ve laid a good foundation but mileage may vary.

The heavy club shield cast is the single greatest movement for the rotator cuff. It's the same motion as a kettlebell halo or Bulgarian bag spin, so the tool itself doesn't really matter too much. Never had a cavity and currently 34. Here's the deal: moderate the amount of sugar you consume;" especially if it's refined. Attempt to avoid all refined sugar. Occasionally, this will be highly inconvenient or annoying. In those cases, let it slide. Otherwise avoid refined sugars. Raw honey is okay unrefined sugar is also fine as an occasional treat. Get plenty of nutrients. Be sure you are getting all the vitamins and minerals your body needs. Brush and floss at night. Flossing is especially important if your teeth are tight.
I don't have a citation, but there was a study done with healthy teeth in a Petri dish. One tooth was submerged in honey and the other was in sugar water. The sugar water tooth decayed and developed cavities the honey tooth was unchanged over time. What was understood through that study is that refined sugar pulled minerals from the tooth and unrefined honey does not. I wish they would redo this study with pure cane juice and refined white sugar, but it appears that the denatured molecules of refined sugar are seeking minerals to create homeostasis and teeth are made of minerals so they just pull from whatever is near them. Since real science is never settled, for now, just avoid those white crystals and other forms of refined sweeteners such as corn syrup.

Flossing is necessary to break apart plaque inbetween your teeth. The brush cannot reach them if your teeth are normally sized and appropriately spaced. Sometimes you may even need to floss with dental floss to break it apart and then use a water pick to flush it away.
If you do not floss plaque and bacteria will build up in the gum pockets under your teeth and eat away at your gums, tooth roots, and eventually your jaw bone.

You might be building muscle by lifting weight and losing fat. Muscle is denser than fat, so your weight might not be going down but you will be recomping your body.

Case in point, my weight has been 83~85kg for the last 8 years, I look very different now than I did at the same weight 4 years ago.
If you're not seeing a big enough change yet, clean up your diet a bit and do more cardio.

Again, find your TDEE, eat in a deficit between -300to -600cal, and dial in your macros.

The real key is consistency with your diet and your exercise.

For your protein intake, you want to eat 0.8g of protein for every pound of LEAN mass. The only people who dispute this sell protein powder or roid(they can actually process more). Multiple studies surrounding diet composition have found excess protein depletes testosterone which is the most important factor for gains/fullness/leanness/performance/strength etc etc

I experimented for 10 years or so with diet and found that taking your protein grams times 2 is very close to the amount of carbs you need to adequately process that protein AND power your body. Sugar DOES NOT COUNT. It doesn't work like bread/pasta/potato/rice carbs, occupies the liver, increases insulin (which drops test) and other bad things.
Depending on your cardio and job, you might need more, you might need less. Tweak and track.
Then the rest of your calories come from fat. You need more fat than most people think but less than ketotards think.
Salt intake is proportional to how much you sweat, how many carbs you eat and how much water you drink. I eat a ton of salt. When I'm low, I just can't perform

When I'm training for a comp, I straight up don't eat any sugar of any kind, never ever drink alcohol and do 30minutes of liss or more a day.

As a beginner,you should be focused on getting as strong as possible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69347771
Full body all workout days.
At the gym do heavy compounds and specialty isolation work like leg press, leg extensions, cable work etc.
At home either a full body dumbbell circuit or, a full body workout.

Aim for 3-4 training days. 2 in gym, 1-2 dB work at home.

Example of a full body dB routine:
Lower body: Choose any 3
DB squats 4 x 8-12
DB Bulgarian split squats 4 x 8-12
DB lunges 4 x 12-15
DB RDL 4 x 12-15
DB Single Leg DL 4 x 8-12 (each leg)

Chest: Choose any 3
DB floor press 4 x 12-15
DB incline press 4 x 8-12
DB fly 4 x 12-15
DB front raise (supine grip) 4 x 8-12

Back: Choose any 3
DB reverse fly 4 x 12-15
DB bent over rows 4 x 12-15 (supinated or pronated grip position)
Single arm DB row 4 x 12-15

Pull ups 4 X AMRAP

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69347857
Arms is a no-brainer with DBs.

Biceps:
Standing Curls 5 x 8-12
Concentration Curls 5 x 8-12
Hammer Curls 5 x 8-12

Triceps:
Skull crushers 5 x 12-15
Tricep extension 5 x 12-15
Tricep kickback 5 x 12-15

posts.com:
>>69345743
I've been paid to give my advice to newbies for the better part of a decade (personal trainer).

They only don't listen to you if you don't make a convincing case for why they should.

If you tell a newbie that routine doesn't matter, and they just need to hit each body part twice per week, there are a dozen guys with the newbie's ideal body on social media who said that doing the wrong exercise is killing their gains, so they have no reason to believe that you're right, and the other guys are wrong.

Instead of telling people that they just need to do some lifting, try telling them that any beginner routine is a good way to build lifting habits that will allow them to gain some muscle, lose some fat, and practice movements that they'll need later. When the newbie gets more advanced, they'll naturally get exposed to more ideas that can be tried out to see if they work well, but the important part is to start with a foundation that allows for a baseline of learning.

Sounds like you're gripping incorrectly. You should be using your fingers and not your palms. If you're getting callouses it's because your grip is too high at the start and the weight of the bar pulls the skin down as it settles into your fingers. It should be resting on the joint that connects your fingers to your palms.

PLEASE HELP - I AGED 5 YEARS OVERNIGHT

I'm 28, been blessed with relatively youthful looks. I have never done anything for skincare besides washing my face in the morning.
7 days ago I started treatment for hair loss (Finasteride + Minoxidil).
I think I overdid it with my Minoxidil dosage because I was applying it to my face as well as my scalp, because I wanted a stronger beard.
I got side effects such as tachycardia and headache but i just ignored these.
Cut to today - I wake up and I have HUGE puffy eyes, it looked like I was having an anaphylactic reaction. I ignored this and went about my day, but I noticed that even though the swelling went down my eye area looked really 'off'. I just looked fucking OLD.

On closer inspection I realised that I now had multiple huge wrinkles under my eyes that WERE NOT THERE JUST 1 WEEK AGO.

I also have these horrible dark circles under my eyes that make me look tired and on drugs.

I am absolutely astounded at how quickly my appearance has deteriorated. Before touching this Minoxidil shit, I had looked identical to my 20 year old self. Now I literally look 40 and I am not exaggerating.
PLEASE HELP ME. I do not know the first thing about skincare. I am really hoping that this damage is somehow reversible, with it being so acute in nature. There must surely be some cream or supplement or laser or some shit that I can do to my face to fix it back to how it used to be.

I have obviously discontinued the Minoxidil but I REALLY doubt that this will fix my appearance - I want to stress that I HAVE FUCKING WRINKLES ON MY FACE THAT DID NOT EXIST A WEEK AGO.

WHAT CAN I DO TO MITIGATE OR REVERSE THIS DAMAGE?
TLDR - started minoxidil 1 week ago. Face has rapidly aged and I now have wrinkles and bags under my eyes. My appearance has aged about 5-10 years in the span of this week. Is there anything I can do to reverse or mitigate this damage, given that it so rapid/acute in nature?

Thanks for reading

posts.name: Mussels à la Creole
posts.com:
from my grandma's cookbook, she was from the deep swamps of louisiana

>Dis here stew is simple yet full of flavor, wit da corn, okra, an' summer squash. An' da frog legs an' Cajun seasoning give it a taste dat's truly unique an' authentic, while da optional coconut milk adds a lil' sweetness an' richness. Dis dish be inspired by da Choctaw people an' der traditional cookin' techniques, an' it's sure ta be a hit wit seafood lovers an' anyone lookin' for a taste of da Bayou. >Whether ya enjoy it round da campfire or in da comfort of your own home, dis stew is sure ta satisfy your cravings for delicious an' comforting food.
Ingredients:

- 2 lb fresh mussels, scrubbed and debearded
- 1 stick butter
- 1 small onion, diced
- 2 cloves garlic, minced
- 1 jalapeno pepper, minced
- 1 small summer squash, diced
- 1 cup corn kernels (fresh or frozen)
- 1 cup okra, sliced
- 1 cup water or coconut milk
- 1 tbsp Cajun seasoning
- 1 lb frog legs
- Salt and black pepper, to taste

## Instructions:

1. In a large pot or Dutch oven, melt the butter over medium heat.
2. Add the onion, garlic, and jalapeno pepper to the pot and sauté for 5 minutes, or until the vegetables are soft.
3. Add the summer squash, corn, okra, water or coconut milk, Cajun seasoning, salt, and black pepper to the pot. Stir to combine and bring the mixture to a boil.
4. If using frog legs, add them to the pot and stir to combine.
5. Reduce the heat to a simmer and simmer the stew for about 20 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender and the frog legs are cooked through.
6. Add the mussels to the pot and stir to combine.
7. Simmer the stew for an additional 5-10 minutes, or until the mussels are cooked through and have opened.
8. Serve the stew hot, garnished with chopped fresh herbs if desired. Enjoy!

posts.name: Poulet aux Pois Chiches et Grits
posts.com:
>>69353012
Her great grandmother was 100% choctaw

Ingredients:

- 1-3 lbs chicken backs (use as many as you'd like, but at least 1 lb)
- 1 large onion, diced
- 1 bell pepper, diced
- 4 jalapeno peppers, diced
- 6 cloves garlic, minced
- 2 lbs turnips, peeled and cubed
- 6 cups chicken broth
- 2 cups water
- 2 cups grits
- 2 tbsp butter
- 4 tbsp Cajun blend spice
- 1 cup radishes, thinly sliced
- Salt and black pepper, to taste

Instructions:

1. If possible, roast the chicken backs over a fire until they are charred on the outside and cooked through. Alternatively, you can brown the chicken backs in a pan on the stove.
- To char the chicken backs over a fire: Build a fire and let it burn down until you have a bed of hot coals. Place the chicken backs directly on the coals and cook for about 10-15 minutes, turning occasionally, until they are charred on the outside and cooked through.
- To brown the chicken backs in a pan: Heat a drizzle of oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add the chicken backs and brown on all sides for about 5-7 minutes. Remove the chicken backs from the pan and set aside.
2. In the same pan, add the onion, bell pepper, jalapeno peppers, and garlic. Sauté for 5 minutes, or until the vegetables are soft.
3. Transfer the vegetables to a crock pot.
4. Add the turnips to the crock pot and stir to combine
5. Pour in the chicken broth and water, and stir to combine.
6. Add the chicken backs to the crock pot.
7. Cover the crock pot and cook on low heat for 6-8 hours, or until the turnips are tender.
8. In a separate pot, bring 2 cups of water to a boil.
9. Stir in the grits and cook for about 5-7 minutes, or until the grits are soft and have absorbed the water.
10. Stir the cooked grits into the crock pot, along with the butter, Cajun blend spice, radishes, salt, and black pepper.
11. Stir to combine and cook for an additional 30 minutes.
12. Serve the stew hot, garnished with chopped fresh herbs

I smoked weed every day for about 2 weeks recently and I have a very low tolerance for it
Things I learned as someone who is hyper aware of their body and noticing when it's out of tune
>your REM sleep WILL be affected and there are days where you will absolutely wake up more tired than you are
>sometimes this fatigue sets in faster than it usually does, making work a complete pain in the fucking ass
>your day will be bent around smoking weed - as soon as you do so, your day is gone
>you become entirely complacent with being bored and doing nothing because time goes by in an instant
>outside of the initial high, nothing seems interesting to you anymore. I couldnt be bothered to talk to my friends, I couldn't give a fuck about cleaning up my place
I literally only smoke weed on Friday and Saturday nights if I know I'm not doing shit that night or the next day

I've seen so many variations on this concept and it always comes down to two groups .

1. Sensible intelligent people who have seen dog brutality or just have enough common sense to know better.
2. Over compensating retards who think they can beat it up or that one retard who actually said he could choke it out.(point and laugh)

Without intellect humans are very low on the food chain, it's because we lack offensive physical characteristics. We don't have claws or sharp teeth, we have a high center of gravity, and are extremely fragile and much more susceptible to the elements.

I saw a pit bull go after a horse once in Mexico, the horse kicked it full blast several times then stomped on it, after the horse left it just got up and walked away. A human would be dead.

Kicks and punches would glance off the dog, and it would just need one good bite to a artery or vital point, even to those with a knife they would end up with defensive wounds or worse if they weren't properly trained.

If a dog comes at you intending to do harm. Use a gun or blunt weapon to keep it at a distance, and keep going even if it squeals until motionless.

Signed the guy who trains K-9 units for a living.

Stuff to try after all the sleep hygiene stuff people always mention that doesn't always work, in order:
Low dose melatonin (300mcg-2mg MAX, more is counterintuitive, can try extended release melatonin too)
Doxylamine (restavit) or other anti-histamine
Low dose mirtazapine (as low as 7.5mg)
Ultra low-dose quetiapine (MAX of like 25-50mg, some people can cut a 25mg into quarters and get good sleep on as low as that). It's technically an "anti-psychotic" but dopaminergic effects are at 300mg-800mg, this dosage is basically a strong anti-histamine

>>69351322
Blue Jay's are nice to look at but God are they annoying and greedy. They will eat my whole feeder of peanuts in a day and come back squaking for more the next

Woodpeckers are fun. They can be invasive if your house has exposed wood. Although I love seeing their red Mohawks

Song birds are cute. Fun to listen too. Although they don't ever shut up in the morning.

There are some other fun birds where I'm at in northern Indiana. I've seen a couple hawks, and herrings in my own backyard.

Cardinals are literally your basic bitches of the bird world. Fun to look at but they don't do anything except eat and look pretty.

I saw a bird the other day that looked like a leopard. Can't really find a good picture of it in my bird book. But it was very interesting when I saw it

Now a real treat to see are humming birds. You have to set out food the night before and catch them in the early morning but once they become regulars they consistently show up throughout the day as long as you keep the sugar water fresh

ok nigger here’s how to.

warm up with a very light set of hammer curls and bands or cable extensions back to back, like 20-30 reps. find variations that don’t fuck with your elbows, and lighten the weight because you’re probably going too heavy.

for me bent over leaning away from the cable overhead extensions feel great and don’t hurt my elbows like french press.

use a slow as fuck tempo and do sets of 15-25. also on your last set do 2-4 rest pause sets. ex: do 15 reps to failure, rest 10 seconds, get 4 reps, rest 10 seconds, 3 reps etc… my arms have grown noticeably in the past 6 ish weeks because i’ve been going very intense on only about 3 sets a sesh 2-3 times a week.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69336439
1. The further north of the equator you go, the less UVA and UVB radiation actually makes it to the surface any time of the year due to the angle of the atmosphere relative to the sun. This makes you need much longer time in the sun to get the same effects, which is even worse in the winter where the angle weakens the sun's radiation even further.

2. You need 15-20 minutes of direct southern summer sun with 20-25% of your skin exposed to it, which is not so easy when it's 10-20F outside all day on a "warm" day and you need to cover up to avoid frostbite. In the winter in the north you might need 2-3 times that amount of time (due to point 1) which means staying outside for up to an hour with no shirt on in below freezing or potentially even below-zero weather.

3. The sky is overcast almost always in the winter so it's rare to actually even get direct sunlight that isn't filtered through clouds in the first place. I go outside multiple times per day and I haven't seen direct sunlight in over a week.

It's not as simple as "just go outside for a bit." Even if us northerners DO go outside in the winter we're not getting any direct sunlight and only a very small amount of our skin (face and MAYBE hands) is exposed to this very weak and overcast sun. Even with super pale complexion it's not enough and supplementation is necessary to maintain healthy vitamin D levels.

posts.com:
While several studies in normal people failed to find any protective effects from vitamin D, others have been more worrying. One 2015 randomised study of 409 elderly people in Finland suggested that vitamin D failed to offer any benefits compared to placebo or exercise - and that fracture rates were, in fact, slightly higher.

The usual prescribed dose in most countries is 800 to 1,000 units per day (so 24,000-30,000 units per month). However, two randomised trials found that at around 40,000 to 60,000 units per month Vitamin D effectively became a dangerous substance.

One study involving over 2,000 elderly Australians, which was largely ignored at the time, and the one just published found that patients given high doses of vitamin D or those on lower doses that increased vitamin D blood levels within the optimal range (as defined by bone specialists) had a 20-30% increased rate of fractures and falls compared to those on low doses or who failed to reach "optimal blood levels".
